docs.lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (BET) DON'T TRIP . . . HE AIN'T THROUGH WITH ME YET! -- Mr. Zoot Suit, the comedian Steve Harvey (above), keeps it clean as he revels in faith, family, preachers and relationships in this stand-up routine taped before church folk at Bishop T. D. Jakes's MegaFest, a four-day evangelical festival in Atlanta. Listen up: underneath the laugh lines lurk words of wisdom. 8 P.M. (Showtime) DIARY OF A MAD BLACK WOMAN (2005). Hell hath no fury, especially when Madea is working on behalf of the scorned. In this adaptation of his revenge play about a woman whose husband of 18 years boots her out of their mansion, Tyler Perry revs up his gun-packing, extra-extra- large grandmother, whose idea of dividing community property requires a chain saw. 9 P.M. (Discovery) DIRTY JOBS: JOBS THAT BITE . . . HARDER -- Mike Rowe mingles with people who earn their livings working with toothy terrors, including some that make plaster molds of live sharks for fiberglass replicas and others who make shark-proof diving suits. Problem is, it's his turn to test the things. (Cue the ''Jaws'' theme.) 9 P.M. (13) BILL MOYERS ON FAITH AND REASON -- Why does an elementary teacher reared in New York and schooled at Miss Porter's and Berkeley decide to become a Buddhist nun? Tonight, in this series' eighth and last installment, Pema Chodron (above right) talks with Mr. Moyers about the spiritual search that led her to this ancient Eastern practice, and why more and more harried Westerners are turning to it in an effort to slow down. 9 P.M. (TLC) WHAT NOT TO WEAR -- Nancy G., a 34-year-old single mother, dresses like she feels, in worn-out cardigans and flannel pajama pants. Stacy and Clinton help wake up her wardrobe. 9 P.M. (USA) MONK -- Natalie persuades Monk to go into business as a private eye, but his first case, a fender bender, is no mere bump in the road. 9 P.M. (BBC America) EDDIE IZZARD: GLORIOUS -- No topic is off-limits in this taping from Mr. Izzard's 1997 stand-up tour, in which he sputters and spews out one-liners like a human equivalent of Google. His riff on air terror, in which the evildoer is a cookie-snatching pilot, may not hit the same comic heights these days. But if you're not laughing with Mr. Izzard (above), you'll be laughing at him, or at least his get-up: shiny apple-red suit, frosted shag and glittery fingernails. 10 P.M. (Discovery) SCIENCE OF SHARK SEX -- Gray sharks mating. You may want to cover your eyes. KATHRYN SHATTUCK

docs.snippet: In a continuing effort to digitize as many books as possible, Google has signed a deal with the University of California to scan many of its 34 million volumes and make them searchable online through the Google Book Search program. The University ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In a continuing effort to digitize as many books as possible, Google has signed a deal with the University of California to scan many of its 34 million volumes and make them searchable online through the Google Book Search program. The University of California has 100 libraries on 10 campuses. The university system has already started digitizing some of its own collections, so Google's efforts will be complementary, said Adam Smith, group business product manager for Google Search. The University of California libraries join other Google library partners, including the University of Michigan, Harvard, Stanford, the New York Public Library, Oxford University and the Library of Congress. Google is not paying the University of California system for the right to scan its books. Mr. Smith said Google planned to make available the full texts of all public domain titles that it scans, but that for books still in copyright, it would provide only ''short snippets or bibliographic information.'' Google's plans have been the subject of controversy in the publishing industry, and the company has been sued by several publishers and authors who are challenging Google's right to scan books that are still under copyright. Mr. Smith said Google believed its use of small portions of the books was ''consistent with the fair use'' laws that permit the replication of copyrighted material. MOTOKO RICH

[C1.] SHARES ADVANCE -- Stocks rose for a second day after the Federal Reserve suggested it might put off interest-rate increases, outweighing the biggest drop in consumer confidence in almost a year. [C8.] PAPER COUPONS SURVIVE -- An Internet assault on the paper-clipping coupon business is under way, but while the cool logic of efficiency suggests the traditional paper coupon is in imminent peril, the marketplace tells another story. [C1.] HOUSEHOLD INCOME EDGES UP -- The nation's median household income rose slightly faster than inflation last year for the first time in six years, the Census Bureau reported. [A1.] INQUIRY ON AGENCY HEAD -- State Department investigators have found that Kenneth Y. Tomlinson, the head of the agency that oversees most government broadcasts to foreign countries, used government employees to do his personal errands and that he billed the government for more days of work than the rules permit. [A1.] VETO OF WINE BILL -- Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger has vetoed a bill that would have declared zinfandel to be the ''historic wine'' of California. [A12.] GOT FAME? -- Faced with declining milk consumption by teenagers, dairy companies are embarking on an ad campaign with sports and entertainment celebrities and interactive features that they hope will win young people over. Advertising. [C3.] BOOKSELLER INQUIRY -- Barnes & Noble said that it had received a subpoena from a United States attorney requesting documents on its stock options practices. [C3.] WORKERS BRIEFED ON FORD -- Local union leaders at the Ford Motor Company received an update on the struggling company's condition, but said they were not told about any specific steps the company planned to take. [C3.] METALS DEAL MOVES FORWARD -- The nickel mining company Inco confirmed its support for a friendly offer from Phelps Dodge after it failed to persuade a Brazilian company to increase a hostile takeover bid of $18 billion. [C4.] FREE AND LEGAL MUSIC -- A new online music company called SpiralFrog said that it would make a huge catalog of songs from the world's largest record company, the Universal Music Group, available for consumers to download free. [C5.] GOOGLE CHIEF ON APPLE'S BOARD -- Apple Computer said that the chief executive of Google, Eric Schmidt, was joining its board. [C5.] KRAFT WANTS INDEPENDENCE -- Kraft Foods, the packaged food company, has been itching to be independent of its parent, the Altria Group, and its tobacco units Philip Morris USA and Philip Morris International. Today's meeting of Altria's board may bring Kraft one step closer to its goal. [C1.] NOVELL'S PROFIT UP -- The business software maker Novell posted a higher quarterly profit and said that it had begun an internal investigation into previous stock options grants. [C5.] J.& J. WINS ANTITRUST SUIT -- Johnson & Johnson won an antitrust lawsuit that had accused the company of illegally using its sutures monopoly to increase sales of other surgical products. [C7.] HOME DEPOT REVISES BYLAWS -- Home Depot took another step to repair its image with investors after an acrimonious annual meeting in May, announcing that it had revised company bylaws to require that each director be elected by majority vote. docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-14 Peace in Darfur at Risk, As New Conflict Looms Negotiations over a proposed United Nations force to shore up the shaky peace in Darfur have limped along with no sign of compromise. The opposing sides in the conflict now seem headed toward a large-scale military confrontation. A1 Allies Ready Sanctions for Iran With Iran defying the deadline to halt production of nuclear fuel, the United States and three European allies are assembling a list of sanctions they would seek in the United Nations Security Council that would begin by restricting imports of nuclear material. A1 52 Die in Iraq Sectarian Attacks Shootings and hidden bombs at an Iraqi market, a gas station and an army recruiting center killed at least 52 people, continuing a wave of sectarian violence that has claimed roughly 200 lives this week. Despite the spike in violence, the top United States general in Iraq said Iraqi forces could take over security as early as next year. A10 Israel Spurns U.N. Request Israel's prime minister, Ehud Olmert, rebuffed a request from the United Nations secretary general, Kofi Annan, for even a partial lifting of the seven-week-old blockade of Lebanon to allow Beirut's airport to resume normal operations. A12 A continuing Israeli offensive in the Gaza Strip killed nine people, including four civilians, one of them a 14-year-old. Israelis announced the discovery of a 150-yard tunnel stretching from a house toward the Karni cargo crossing, which Israel had closed due to security alerts, between Gaza and Israel. A14 Sri Lanka Blamed in Aid Killings Swedish-led cease-fire monitors accused the Sri Lankan government security forces of killing 17 aid workers in the town of Mutur in one of the worst attacks against humanitarian workers worldwide in recent years. The monitors cited several reasons, including confidential conversations with ''highly reliable sources'' that they said pointed to the culpability of the security forces. A12 ARTS E1-10 Fake Letter in Poet's Biography A. N. Wilson, one of London's most visible literary figures, was duped into printing a made-up love letter in ''Betjeman,'' his book about the British poet laureate John Betjeman. In the fake document, the first letters of each sentence, except the first, spell out an insulting sentence that starts with Mr. Wilson's name and ends with a vulgarity. E1 Chicago Critic Criticized Hedy Weiss, a theater critic for The Chicago Sun-Times for more than 20 years, is facing criticism herself after publishing scathing comments about a weekend-long festival of musicals in progress, called Stages. Edward Albee and Tony Kushner are among those who have voiced their objections. E3 NATIONAL A16-22 California Announces Deal To Curb Greenhouse Gases California's political leaders announced an agreement that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate change. A1 Some Colleges Ignoring SAT's For many small liberal arts colleges the SAT may have outlived its usefulness. More than a quarter of the U.S. News and World Report's Top 100 liberal arts colleges have made college admissions exams optional. A1 Destruction of Ballots Delayed With paper ballots from the 2004 presidential election in Ohio scheduled to be destroyed, the Ohio secretary of state said that he would move to delay the destruction. Since the election, questions have been raised about how votes were tallied. A16 Los Angeles School Overhaul Los Angeles passed the reins of its troubled public schools to the mayor in measure passed by the State Legislature. But the legislation gives little real power to the mayor, and, school governance experts said, lacks accountability. A16 Conservation Policy Adopted The National Park Service will adopt a policy emphasizing conservation of natural resources over recreation when they are in conflict. A16 NEW YORK/REGION B1-8 Plan for Accused Priests: Be Monitored, or Resign Cardinal Edward M. Egan, head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, has a new plan for dealing with priests who, although credibly accused of sexually abusing children, cannot be defrocked for various reasons. They can spend the rest of their lives in closely supervised housing, or they can leave the priesthood. B1 Challenge to Housing Goals The Bloomberg administration's aim to preserve much of the city's moderate-income housing amid skyrocketing prices is facing serious challenges, as illustrated by the possible sale of Stuyvesant Town and Peter Cooper Village along the East River, long a bastion of middle-class residents. B1 Lawyer Charged in Killing A lawyer in Fairfield, Conn., has been charged with murder after the police say he climbed through his neighbor's window and stabbed him to death shortly after hearing that the neighbor had molested the lawyer's 2-year-old daughter. B1 OBITUARIES A22-23 Glenn Ford A laconic, soft-spoken actor with an easy smile who played leading roles in many westerns, melodramas and romantic films from the early 1940's through the 60's, he was 90. docs.lead_paragraph: SILICON VALLEY POWER ALLIANCE When Google's chief executive, Eric E. Schmidt, left, was named to Apple Computer's board this week, the announcement touched off a wave of speculation about the motives of the man behind the move: Apple's co-founder, Steven P. Jobs. [Page A1.] CALIFORNIA EMISSIONS BILL California's political leaders announced an agreement that imposes the most sweeping controls on carbon-dioxide emissions in the nation, putting the state at the forefront of a broad campaign to curb the man-made causes of climate change despite resistance in Washington. [A1.] FILLING UP ON CORN A 2,100-mile drive through the region where ethanol fuel is most popular revealed that despite all the good will toward E-85, as the corn-based fuel blend is known, its success is far from assured. [C1.] LOOPHOLE FOR FLEXIBLE FUEL As car companies promote E-85 as an alternative to gasoline, they are benefiting from a loophole that allows them to receive credits toward environmental standards when they sell flexible-fuel vehicles that run on the ethanol-based fuel. [C4.] ECONOMY EXPANDED IN QUARTER The economy grew more quickly in the second quarter than initially estimated and inflation was slightly lower, the Commerce Department reported. [C1.] STOCKS EDGE UP The Dow average and the Nasdaq rose slightly in thin trading, helped by a government report showing economic growth remains reasonably strong. [C13.] JITTERS OVER HURRICANES All along the coasts, from Texas to New England, insurers suffering from hurricane jitters are raising rates and cutting back on coverage. But nowhere is the crisis more severe than in Florida, where storms in recent years have added billions to the insurers' losses. [C1.] PESSIMISM AMONG WORKERS Three new opinion polls found deep pessimism among American workers, with most saying that wages were not keeping pace with inflation and that workers were worse off in many ways than a generation ago. [A21.] ALCATEL DEFENDS LUCENT DEAL With a week to go before a crucial vote on a deal that would reshape the telecommunications equipment industry, Alcatel disputed criticism about its planned takeover of Lucent and insisted that the deal would benefit shareholders. [C3.] COKE EXECUTIVE LEAVES The president of Coca-Cola's North American unit, Donald R. Knauss, resigned abruptly to become chairman and chief executive of Clorox. [C3.] G.M. DROPS 'SURVIVOR' ADS General Motors has decided not to advertise on the CBS reality show ''Survivor'' for the upcoming season, one that has attracted criticism because teams of contestants are being pitted against each other based on race. Advertising. [C3.] NEW ALUMINUM GIANT Alcoa may face a rival for global dominance if a tentative merger of two Russian aluminum companies and a major Swiss commodity trader comes to fruition. Should Alcoa drop from its No. 1 spot it would be partly a reflection of wider industrial shifts that now favor Russia's commodity-driven economy. [C5.] TiVo'S LOSS CLIMBS TiVo reported a quarterly loss that was seven times the size of its loss a year ago, largely because of hefty legal costs associated with a high-stakes intellectual property patent dispute. [C4.] NOT GUILTY PLEA IN OPTIONS CASE The former chief executive of Brocade Communications Systems, Gregory L. Reyes, pleaded not guilty to 12 counts of securities fraud and other charges that he improperly backdated employee stock option grants. [C11.] NO ACTION ON SHELL'S EX-CHIEF The Securities and Exchange Commission has decided to take no action against Sir Philip Watts, the former chief executive of Royal Dutch Shell, over the 2004 scandal involving the overbooking of oil reserves. [C11.] REVERSAL OF VIOXX AWARD Merck won the first reversal of a damage award over its Vioxx painkiller when a judge said that a $51 million verdict was ''grossly excessive.''
